history.content:
Not sure what you mean by theoretical security, but I believe there are cryptography courses offered by the math and cs departments.

What topic in 161 specifically interested you?

children.subject: OP Here. I actually asked that question!

If you're considering CS276, Math 113 (abstract algebra) and Math 116 (crypto) might interest you as well. In particular I have heard that CS276 is mostly focused on constructions/applications, so if it's the mathematics of crypto that interest you Math 116 might be more relevant. There's also CS172 if complexity theory is more your thing.

history.content:
I'm interested in studying the theoretical foundations of information security. I have CS 161 level security knowledge as well as a little research experience at Berkeley in security. I'm considering taking CS 276 next semester.

However, I'm wondering whether there are any other theoretical security courses. I know we have CS 261 but the material doesn't seem theoretical, but more of a 161 extension. I might be wrong. Another idea I had was to take information theory - but I don't know how useful that would be.

I thought I'd ask the Professors here for help. Thank you in advance!
